abstract: Scientists discover enzyme that plays into development of Alzheimer's disease, opening door to developing drugs that might block it and, if drugs prove safe, to preventing or slowing the disease; discovery of enzyme had eluded teams of scientists at universities and drug companies for more than decade, although they had given it a name, beta-secretase; so many false claims of victory were announced that investigators automatically doubted anyone who claimed to have found it; but experts say that new work by Dr Martin Citron and his colleagues at Amgen, biotechnology company in Thousand Oaks, Calif, is different--that it passes crucial tests of authenticity, convincing even some skeptics; report appears in Oct 22 issue of Science (M)
snippet: Scientists discover enzyme that plays into development of Alzheimer's disease, opening door to developing drugs that might block it and, if drugs prove safe, to preventing or slowing the disease; discovery of enzyme had eluded teams of scientists ...
lead_paragraph: The long, brutal process that leads to Alzheimer's disease starts when a single enzyme snips a protein that protrudes from brain cells, leading to the release of toxic shards. Now scientists report that they have found that enzyme, opening the door to developing drugs that might block it and, if the drugs prove safe, to preventing or slowing the disease.
headline.main: Scientists Find Enzyme Linked To Alzheimer's
headline.print_headline: Scientists Find Enzyme Linked To Alzheimer's

abstract: Pangea Systems, whose 'bioinformatic' software provides access to genetic data spawned by Human Genome Project, is about to launch Doubletwist.com, a new Web site intended to make on-line genetic and biological research fast, easy and available to any amateur or professional biologist; test phase will be limited to student body and faculty of Stanford University; eventually casual users will be able to access information at no charge, while heavy users will pay for it on a sliding scale, but far less than the $500,000 or more Pangea now charges big pharmaceutical companies; other bioinformatics companies may soon follow suit; some industry executives foresee the day when an educated consumer might take a CD-ROM containing a laboratory's rendering of his genetic profile, and combine it with a Web surf through gene libraries to determine his predisposition toward adverse drug reactions, for example, or for Alzheimer's disease, colon cancer or other afflictions that might eventually be treatable through gene therapy; photos (M)

abstract: Scientists have known for years that to forestall or treat Alzheimer's disease they needed to prevent hard balls of debris from accumulating in the brain. Now researchers at Amgen have taken the first step toward that goal. They found an elusive enzyme that snips a brain protein in two, initiating the formation of the debris. The next challenge, experts say, is to find a drug that will block that enzyme. If the scientific theory is correct, such a drug might halt the death of brain cells in people with the disease and even prevent the disease in people destined to get it.   GINA KOLATA
lead_paragraph: Scientists have known for years that to forestall or treat Alzheimer's disease they needed to prevent hard balls of debris from accumulating in the brain. Now researchers at Amgen have taken the first step toward that goal. They found an elusive enzyme that snips a brain protein in two, initiating the formation of the debris. The next challenge, experts say, is to find a drug that will block that enzyme. If the scientific theory is correct, such a drug might halt the death of brain cells in people with the disease and even prevent the disease in people destined to get it. GINA KOLATA

abstract: Suzanne Cloud disputes Steve Gettinger's August 15 column calling Alzheimer's disease a grace, cocoon and escape (S)
snippet: Suzanne Cloud disputes Steve Gettinger's August 15 column calling Alzheimer's disease a grace, cocoon and escape (S)
lead_paragraph: To call Alzheimer's disease ''a grace, a cocoon, an escape into the pure moment,'' sent shivers through me. Gettinger confuses a Zen moment with successive periods of mental blankness that engender no reflection at all. A patient in the end stages of this disease could be looking at a flower or a shoot-'em-up on TV and not know the difference. I understand that he needs to put the best face on the experience of dealing with his mother's disease, but saying that forgetfulness ''set her free'' is ludicrous. The sooner a treatment is found the better.
headline.main: The Zen of Alzheimer's
headline.print_headline: The Zen of Alzheimer's

abstract: Jack M Pollock letter on Steve Gettinger's August 15 column recalls his wife's death from Alzheimer's (S)
snippet: Jack M Pollock letter on Steve Gettinger's August 15 column recalls his wife's death from Alzheimer's (S)
lead_paragraph: I read Steve Gettinger's Lives column (Aug. 15) with more than a touch of rue. My wife died of Alzheimer's eight years ago. In no way was the disease a blessing. It took away my wife's ability to think, to speak, to walk and, finally, to breathe. Then, when it had nothing more to take, it took her. She was not one of the lucky ones. It was not easy to say goodbye.
headline.main: The Zen of Alzheimer's
headline.print_headline: The Zen of Alzheimer's

abstract: Kathryn Ewing letter on Steve Gettinger's August 15 column holds Alzheimer's disease holds few blessings (S)
snippet: Kathryn Ewing letter on Steve Gettinger's August 15 column holds Alzheimer's disease holds few blessings (S)
lead_paragraph: Yes, there are endearing things that happen; even funny things. But, oh, the pain of watching that bright, glancing mind falter, fail, at last grow dark. Moments of childlike pleasure do indeed present themselves, but with such a pang for what once was. No, this vicious disease confers few blessings.
headline.main: The Zen of Alzheimer's
headline.print_headline: The Zen of Alzheimer's

abstract: Seena Dittelman letter on Steve Gettinger's column on Alzheimer's disease recalls her mother's habit of hugging people at assisted-care facility (S)
snippet: Seena Dittelman letter on Steve Gettinger's column on Alzheimer's disease recalls her mother's habit of hugging people at assisted-care facility (S)
lead_paragraph: My sisters and I lost our mother, Anna Kovitch, two and a half years ago at the age of 91, and many episodes similar to the ones described by Steve Gettinger came to mind. She developed the habit of hugging everyone she came close to in the assisted-care facility. ''Don't be upset,'' one of the recipients of a hug said. ''This is the first hug I've gotten since my husband died.''
headline.main: The Zen of Alzheimer's
headline.print_headline: The Zen of Alzheimer's

abstract: FISHER-Zachary. The scientists, researchers and health professionals of The Zachary and Elizabeth M. Fisher Alzheimer's Disease Education and Resources Program of the New York University School of Medicine are profoundly saddened by the passing of Zachary Fisher. Mr. Fisher's generosity, personal kindness and vision enabled the creation of our program which has permitted us to articulate a new science of Alzheimer's Disease management and to disseminate this information worldwide. All victims of Alzheimer's Disease and their loved ones have lost a true and wonderful friend and ally. Barry Reisberg, M.D., Dir. Sunnie Kenowsky, D.V.M., Co-Director Emile Franssen, M.D. Liduin E.M. Souren, R.N., M.S.N. and our fellow program scientists

abstract: TOBIN-Rae Katz. Age 85, died on Monday, Nov. 29, 1999. The light in Rae's eyes shone with intelligence, love, good humor and wit. With heart and mind, she nurtured her family, fought for a better world and nursed her husband Mike through his terrible battle with Alzheimer's. She left the world a better place. We'll miss this warm and wonderful woman. Rae is survived by her sister Norma Katz Menter, her son Daniel, her daughter and son-in-law Susan and John Schoonover and grandchildren Carl, Danny and Julie. Contributions to Alzheimer's Association, 360 Lexington Avenue, New York, New York 10017.

Beloved grandfather of Jonathan David Besharim, father-in-law of Shlomo, son-in-law of Elsie and Lee Kanner. He will always be with us. abstract: SILVERMAN-Harold. Age 87 years. Died peacefully in his sleep after a long battle with Alzheimer's disease. Beloved and cherished husband of Evelyn, adored father of Nancy and Norman, grandfather of Morgun and William. Harold was a devoted son, husband and father, who used his gifts of uncommon wisdom, compassion and insight to inspire and improve the lives of many who knew him. He rose to meet the many challenges in his own life with indefatigable determination, a clarity of purpose and an abundance of humor. We will miss him. Services today in San Diego, CA. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate a donation to the Alzheimer's Association, 360 Lexington Ave., New York, NY 10017.

abstract: ROGOVIN-Jack. Age 87, passed away on October 17, 1999 in Hollywood, Florida due to complications of pneumonia and a heart attack. Longtime teacher of French, Spanish & Russian and Guidance Counselor at Tilden High School in Brooklyn. Active in the Teachers Union. He served in the Army Signal Corps, South Pacific during W.W.II. Devoted husband of the late Gussie whom he visited faithfully every day for more than a dozen years after she contracted Alzheimers. Survived by numerous loving nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to the Alzheimers Disease and Related Disease Association of Broward County, FL (He was President of the Fort Lauderdale chapter for many years.) Services 11AM Thurs, New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I., NY.

abstract: ROGOVIN-Jack. Age 87, passed away on October 17, 1999 in Hollywood, Florida due to complications of pneumonia and a heart attack. Longtime teacher of French, Spanish & Russian and Guidance Counselor at Tilden High School in Brooklyn. Active in the Teachers Union. He served in the Army Signal Corps, South Pacific during W.W.II. Devoted husband of the late Gussie whom he visited faithfully every day for more than a dozen years after she contracted Alzheimers. Survived by numerous loving nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to the Alzheimers Disease and Related Disease Association of Broward County, FL (He was President of the Fort Lauderdale chapter for many years.) Services 11AM Thurs, New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I., NY.
lead_paragraph: ROGOVIN-Jack. Age 87, passed away on October 17, 1999 in Hollywood, Florida due to complications of pneumonia and a heart attack. Longtime teacher of French, Spanish & Russian and Guidance Counselor at Tilden High School in Brooklyn. Active in the Teachers Union. He served in the Army Signal Corps, South Pacific during W.W.II. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to the Alzheimers Disease and Related Disease Association of Broward County, FL (He was President of the Fort Lauderdale chapter for many years.) Services 11AM Thurs, New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I., NY.

abstract: TIMMERMAN-Robert E. Died July 29, 1999 at the Greenwich Hospital of Alzheimer's disease. Mr. Timmerman was a long-time resident of Greenwich, Conn., but also maintained homes in Palm Beach, Fla., and Kennebunkport, Me. Mr. Timmerman was the son of the late Hearst Publisher Edward W. Timmerman and Maude Ayer Timmerman of Chicago. He is survived by his wife, Paula Reid Timmerman. Mr. Timmerman attended the Taft School and Brown University. During World War II, he was an officer in the Air Corps. During his lifetime, Mr. Timmerman had an active career in the field of advertising, holding senior positions with a number of agencies in New York City. At the time of his retirement, he was a senior vice president with Needham, Harper, Steers. In addition to his business interests, Mr. Timmerman was active in a number of social clubs including the Kennebunk River Club, Greenwich Country Club, Metropolitan Club and the Everglades Club. A private family service will be held in Rhode Island. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Alzheimer's Foundation would be preferred.
lead_paragraph: TIMMERMAN-Robert E. Died July 29, 1999 at the Greenwich Hospital of Alzheimer's disease. During World War II, he was an officer in the Air Corps. abstract: WERNER-Welles. 80, of New York, died August 16, 1999 in Seattle, WA. He was born September 4, 1918 in Brooklyn, NY. abstract: MATTLAGE-Louise. Multi-talented modern dance, artist, and poet died on March 9, 1999, in Boca Raton, FL. She was 92, and the cause was advanced Alzheimer's Disease. A sophisticated woman with a wide range of cultural interests, Ms. Mattlage's career took her from modern dance with Jose Limon, and Doris Humphrey, to director and choreographer of her own dance company, based in CT, called The Dancers of Faith. The Dance Company performed in countless churches and synagogues throughout the eastern United States. She taught modern dance at college and universities all around the world. She was the author of four books of poetry. Her numerous poems and essays were published in periodicals often concerning women's issues. Born and raised in Boston, MA, Ms. Mattlage lived for many years in Fairfield and Southport, CT. She moved to Key Biscayne, FL in 1971. She continued to spend summers in Fairfield, CT. She was a member of the Miami chapter of the Pen Women and she lectured and performed her dance and poetry well into her 80's. In 1989, she moved to Boca Raton, FL. She is survived by her son Jonathan Mattlage of Acworth, GA, her daughter Valerie Mattlage of Boca Raton, FL, and her two grandsons: Jason Ledyard, of New York, NY, and Jonathan Mattlage, Jr. of Kennesaw, GA. She was pre-deceased by her husband of 65 years, W.F.H. Mattlage. Memorial contributions may be made to either the National Organization for Women, or The Alzheimer's Association.
lead_paragraph: MATTLAGE-Louise. Multi-talented modern dance, artist, and poet died on March 9, 1999, in Boca Raton, FL. She was 92, and the cause was advanced Alzheimer's Disease. A sophisticated woman with a wide range of cultural interests, Ms. Mattlage's career took her from modern dance with Jose Limon, and Doris Humphrey, to director and choreographer of her own dance company, based in CT, called The Dancers of Faith. The Dance Company performed in countless churches and synagogues throughout the eastern United States. She taught modern dance at college and universities all around the world. She was the author of four books of poetry. Her numerous poems and essays were published in periodicals often concerning women's issues. Born and raised in Boston, MA, Ms. Mattlage lived for many years in Fairfield and Southport, CT. She moved to Key Biscayne, FL in 1971. She continued to spend summers in Fairfield, CT. She was a member of the Miami chapter of the Pen Women and she lectured and performed her dance and poetry well into her 80's. In 1989, she moved to Boca Raton, FL. She is survived by her son Jonathan Mattlage of Acworth, GA, her daughter Valerie Mattlage of Boca Raton, FL, and her two grandsons: Jason Ledyard, of New York, NY, and Jonathan Mattlage, Jr. of Kennesaw, GA. She was pre-deceased by her husband of 65 years, W.F.H. Mattlage. Memorial contributions may be made to either the National Organization for Women, or The Alzheimer's Association.

abstract: LAPINE-David S. Of Stamford, CT and Lauderhill, FL died on Friday September 3. Survived by his children Phyllis, Mark, Lawrence and James; his nine grandchildren and one great-grandchild. The company which bore Mr. Lapine's name was widely considered a leader in the housewares industry. Mr. Lapine was a past president of the NY Housewares Club as well as active throughout his life on behalf of several charitable organizations. A private burial service will be held on Sunday. Contributions in his memory can be made: the Jewish Home for the Elderly, 175 Jefferson Street, Fairfield, CT 06432; or the Alzheimers Association of Fairfield County, 607 Main Avenue, Norwalk, CT 06851.

abstract: RICHMAN-Pauline Frances (Paula, to the world), on August 2nd, 1999 at age 94. She left us as she lived, peacefully and with dignity. Survived by her son, Gilbert; daughters-in-law, Janice and Ruth; grandchildren, Howard and Jill; great-grandchildren, Betsy and Lee; friends, associates and her special friend and companion, Megan. Services Wednesday, August 4th, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. The family will receive guests prior to the service from noon till 1:15 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Alzheimer's Association or your favorite charity.

abstract: MISTRETTA-Frances V. Formerly of Murray Hill, died at 2:45PM on April 2, 1999 of complications brought about by a stroke at Good Samaritan Nursing Home's Alzheimer Unit in Jasper, IN, where she had resided since 1996. She was born in Brooklyn on August 10, 1911 to Francesco and Christina (Angelo) Mistretta. Surviving are a sister, Lillian Rubino, of Lakehurst, NJ and several nieces and nephews. She had been a travel agent for over 30 years and had previously worked for the City of New York as an Inspector for the Department of Marine and Aviation. She was a graduate of Adelphi College. She was buried at the family plot in Holy Cross Cemetery in Queens.

abstract: CORSON-Richard. On January 13th, 1999. Eminent theatre makeup authority, teacher and author of ''Stage Makeup'' in current use, with the 9th edition forthcoming. His essential reference works include ''Fashions in Hair: The First 5000 Years,'' ''Fashions in Makeup: From Ancient to Modern Times,'' and ''Fashions in Eyeglasses: From the 14th Century to Present Day.'' These definitive reference sources have been translated throughout the world. He taught at USC-Long Beach, was Adjunct Professor at Southern Methodist University, and conducted numerous seminars. He was consultant for productions on and off-Broadway. Contributions in his name may be made to Alzheimer's research.
lead_paragraph: CORSON-Richard. On January 13th, 1999. Eminent theatre makeup authority, teacher and author of ''Stage Makeup'' in current use, with the 9th edition forthcoming. His essential reference works include ''Fashions in Hair: The First 5000 Years,'' ''Fashions in Makeup: From Ancient to Modern Times,'' and ''Fashions in Eyeglasses: From the 14th Century to Present Day.'' These definitive reference sources have been translated throughout the world. He taught at USC-Long Beach, was Adjunct Professor at Southern Methodist University, and conducted numerous seminars. He was consultant for productions on and off-Broadway. Contributions in his name may be made to Alzheimer's research.

abstract: FISHER-Zachary. The partners of Fisher Brothers mourn the passing of our founder and partner Zachary Fisher and express our deepest condolences to his wife, Elizabeth, and the entire Fisher family. Zachary was a proud American, a leading real estate developer and a wonderful person. He helped to build New York City's skyline while devoting much of his life to the men and women in the U.S. Armed Forces. A recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom, Zachary founded the Intrepid Sea Air Space Museum; the Fisher House Program, which provides lodging for families of hospitalized military personnel; and the Fisher Armed Services Foundation, which makes contributions to military families who lose loved ones in tragic circumstances. Zachary also established the Fisher Center for Alzheimer's Disease Research at Rockefeller University. He touched and enriched many lives and will be sorely missed. A private memorial will be held aboard the Intrepid on Monday, June 7. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Intrepid Museum Foundation, 46th Street at 12th Avenue, New York City 10036. Fisher Brothers Larry Fisher Richard L. Fisher M. Anthony Fisher Arnold Fisher Kenneth Fisher Steven Fisher    FISHER-Zachary. The Board of Trustees, faculty, and staff of The Rockefeller University are deeply saddened by the passing of our cherished friend, Zachary Fisher, a true giant in the worlds of real estate and philanthropy. His great generosity and impassioned commitment led to the creation of the Zachary and Elizabeth M. Fisher Center for Alzheimer's Research at Rockefeller. We join all New Yorkers in saluting the enormous accomplishments of his long life, from enhancing the landscape of our City, to furthering biomedical research, to preserving our nation's history through his beloved Intrepid Museum. We will greatly miss him. Our deepest condolences are sent to his wife, Elizabeth, and the entire Fisher family. Arnold J. Levine, President Torsten N. Wiesel, President Emeritus Richard B. Fisher, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman The Rockefeller University    FISHER-Zachary. The scientists and staff of the Zachary and Elizabeth M. Fisher Center for Alzheimer's Research wish to express their heartfelt sorrow over the death of Zachary Fisher, whose passion for finding an answer to Alzheimer's is a source of great inspiration to us all. He was a true partner in our efforts to unravel the mysteries of this devastating disease. His encouragement, support, and enormously effective advocacy have benefitted all scientists working at the frontiers of aging research. We are proud to bear the name of this great man, and we will seek to honor his memory through our work. Paul Greengard, Vincent Astor Professor and Director, Zachary and Elizabeth M. Fisher Center for Alzheimer's Research The Rockefeller University    FISHER-Zachary. The Board and Staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the passing of Zachary Fisher, our friend and colleague on the Board of Trustees. Zachary's energy in shaping New York City's physical environment was matched only by his personal gallantry and magnificent philanthropy to so many institutions, and we at Carnegie Hall feel fortunate to have worked with him. Our deep sympathy goes to Elizabeth and the family. Isaac Stern, President Sanford I. Weill, Chairman    FISHER-Zachary. The Officers, Governors and Members of The New York Friars Club mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Friar Zachary Fisher on June 4, 1999. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Services will be held on Monday, June 7th, at 11 AM on the Intrepid. To RSVP, call 212-957-7020. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Exec Director    FISHER-Zachary. Battle Fowler mourns the passing of Zachary Fisher, our good friend and client. An entrepreneur, philanthropist and leader, he touched the lives of countless individuals and organizations. He gave unselfishly of his time, talent and resources for the benefit of those in the military. His generosity, leadership and warmhearted spirit will be missed. We offer our condolences to his wife, Elizabeth, and the Fisher family.    FISHER-Zachary. The Board of Governors and Members of the Boca Rio Golf Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Zachary Fisher, beloved husband of Elizabeth. We extend our deepest sympathy to the family. Boca Rio Golf Club Dr. Ira J. Gelb, President    FISHER-Zachary. The Board of Governors and Members of Brae Burn Country Club record with great sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Zachary Fisher. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his wife, Elizabeth, and his entire family. Len Shendell, President Judith Tarter, Secretary    FISHER-Zachary. The Officers and Members of Old Oaks Country Club mourn the passing of their dear friend and fellow member, Zachary Fisher. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his wife Elizabeth, to his brother Larry, to his children and other members of his family. Samuel G. Weinberg, President    FISHER-Zachary. The Real Estate Board of New York mourns the passing of Zachary Fisher, a shaper of our city's splendid skyline and esteemed colleague and a distinguished public benefactor. We extend our sympathy to the Fisher family. Bernard H. Mendik, Chairperson Steven Spinola, President    FISHER-Zachary. It has been our privilege, for 50 years, to call Zachary our dearest and best friend. He was a saint in the true meaning of the word. His caring, exceptional. We shall miss him every day. Peg and Sy Candee

abstract: WEISER-Eileen, 70. Of Chappaqua, NY, passed away Sunday, January 31, 1999. A loving mother, supportive friend, businesswoman and teacher, Eileen was born on January 31, 1929 in New York City. She is survived by her daughter, Jane Weiser Kleinman, and husband, Dan, of Chappaqua, NY, their children, Josh, Adam and Jake, her son, Jeffrey Weiser, and wife Beverly Weiser, of Sugar Land, Texas, and their children, Shelby, Rebecca, and Robert, and numerous other loving family and friends. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, February 3rd at 10:30 A.M. at Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, New York, with burial shortly thereafter in Valhalla, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The National Alzheimers Association.

abstract: SOD-Louis M., M.D. Died October 16, 1999 at the age of 73 due to diabetes and Alzheimer's disease. He is survived by his wife, Cynthia; his son and daughter-in-law, Paul and Matty; his son, Eric; his daughter, Ruth; six grandchildren, Yanky, Yossi, Batsheva, Baila, Rafi and Zev; his siter and brother-in-law, Pauline & Gilbert Levin of Norfolk, VA. Dr. Sod was raised in Norfolk, VA. and resided in Bergen County, NJ. He was Chief of Radiology at various hospitals including Byrd S. Coller Memorial Hospital, St. Claire's Hospital in Denville, NJ., and a professor of radiology at New York Medical College.

abstract: BLACK-Edward. Age 90. Beloved husband for 63 years of Muriel Fleischman Black, wonderful father of Jo Ann and Howard Chase, adored and adoring Grandpa Eddie to Adam Chase, loving brother to five siblings and Uncle Eddie to every child he ever met. He was ''The Baron'' of the New York Journal American for many years before going into the public relations business. He served in Great Britain in World War II. Eddie was blessed with an extraordinarily outgoing personality, a great sense of humor and genuine kindness and generosity to all who crossed his path. Services were held Sunday, October 10, in Miami. Contributions in his memory may be made to ''Alzheimer's Care Committee/Notables'' of Douglas Gardens, 5200 Northeast Second Avenue, Miami, FL 33137.

abstract: WIMSATT-Margaret Elizabeth Hecht died November 22, 1999. She was born in Chicago, IL, February 26, 1919, to the late Frank Abner and Margaret Lipps Hecht. She is survived by her son, James Velvet Wimsatt, and her daughter-in-law, Nancy Lee Abbey, of Hamden, CT. She was predeceased by her son, Alexander Wimsatt, a student, and her husband, William Kurtz Wimsatt Jr., Sterling Professor of English at Yale University. She was a graduate of the University of Chicago and Yale. She was a poet, reviewer, essayist and a teacher of English composition at the University of New Mexico and Yale. She was a resident of New Haven, CT. from 1941-1997. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be sent to the South Central CT Chapter of the Alzheimer's Association, 2911 Dixwell Avenue, Hamden, CT. 06518. For information: The Hawley Lincoln Memorial, 493 Whitney Avenue, New Haven, CT.
lead_paragraph: WIMSATT-Margaret Elizabeth Hecht died November 22, 1999. She was born in Chicago, IL, February 26, 1919, to the late Frank Abner and Margaret Lipps Hecht. She is survived by her son, James Velvet Wimsatt, and her daughter-in-law, Nancy Lee Abbey, of Hamden, CT. She was predeceased by her son, Alexander Wimsatt, a student, and her husband, William Kurtz Wimsatt Jr., Sterling Professor of English at Yale University. She was a graduate of the University of Chicago and Yale. She was a poet, reviewer, essayist and a teacher of English composition at the University of New Mexico and Yale. She was a resident of New Haven, CT. from 1941-1997. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be sent to the South Central CT Chapter of the Alzheimer's Association, 2911 Dixwell Avenue, Hamden, CT. 06518. For information: The Hawley Lincoln Memorial, 493 Whitney Avenue, New Haven, CT.

abstract: FISHER-Zachary. The partners of Fisher Brothers mourn the passing of our founder and partner Zachary Fisher and express our deepest condolences to his wife, Elizabeth, and the entire Fisher family. Zachary was a proud American, a leading real estate developer and a wonderful person. He helped to build New York City's skyline while devoting much of his life to the men and women in the U.S. Armed Forces. A recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom, Zachary founded the Intrepid Sea Air Space Museum; the Fisher House Program, which provides lodging for families of hospitalized military personnel; and the Fisher Armed Services Foundation, which makes contributions to military families who lose loved ones in tragic circumstances. Zachary also established the Fisher Center for Alzheimer's Disease Research at Rockefeller University. He touched and enriched many lives and will be sorely missed. A private memorial will be held aboard the Intrepid on Monday, June 7. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Intrepid Museum Foundation, 46th Street at 12th Avenue, New York City 10036. Fisher Brothers Larry Fisher Richard L. Fisher M. Anthony Fisher Arnold Fisher Kenneth Fisher Steven Fisher    FISHER-Zachary. The officers, leadership and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the death of Zachary Fisher, a magnanimous benefactor and dedicated philanthropist. Equally generous to many causes that benefit all New Yorkers, he leaves a dynamic legacy visible in the skyline of his beloved city. With great sensitivity he improved the lives of many people throughout our nation whose tragedies, if not faces, were known to him. He will always be remembered for his outstanding commitment to the State of Israel, and to Jewish communities in danger throughout the world. With his help, the American Jewish community was able to rescue generations of Jews from harm's way. His adherence to the highest standards of philanthropy enables us to continue to provide a diverse network of human services throughout our metropolitan region. It was our great privilege to merit his unique friendship. We extend our sincere sympathies to his wife Elizabeth, step-son Bill Crovello, brother Larry, sister Ginny Ross, and all the members of the family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.    FISHER-Zachary. On behalf of the entire New York University School of Medicine community, we note with great sorrow the passing of Zachary Fisher, a longtime generous benefactor and good friend. With his wife, Mr. Fisher established the Zachary and Elizabeth M. Fisher Alzheimer's Disease Education and Resources Program which will speed our scientists in their quest to understand one of today's most devastating illnesses. We will miss him deeply and offer our sincere condolences to his wife, Elizabeth; his brother, Larry; and sister Ginny; and his stepson, Bill Crovello. Henry R. Silverman, Chairman Board of Trustees NYU School of Medicine Robert M. Glickman, MD Dean, NYU School of Medicine    FISHER-Zachary. His colleagues at the Ellis Island Restoration Commission mourn the death of their dedicated and beloved fellow Board Member, Zachary Fisher, whose devotion to the restoration of Ellis Island and the development of a Family History Center were inspirational. We extend our deepest sympathy to Elizabeth and his family. Zach's efforts will not be in vain. Philip Lax, President Norman Liss, VP of Development Jacqueline Beusse, VP Dr. August Bolino, VP Set Charles Momjian, VP Eunice Whittlesey, Secretary Howard Slotnick, Treasurer    FISHER-Zachary. We were deeply grieved and saddened to learn of the untimely passing of our good friend, Zachary Fisher. A generous champion in the struggle against Alzheimer's disease, his leadersip and commitment will be sorely missed. Our hearts go out to the Fisher family and especially to our fellow Director, Dr. Sunnie Kenowsky. William M. Brachfeld, President Marilyn Cohen, Co-President John Jager, Exec. Director Jean Marks, Assoc. Exec. Director Alzheimers Assn. NYC Chapter    FISHER-Zachary. Temple Israel of the City of New York mourns the death of Zachary Fisher, cherished trustee and friend. Our sincere condolences to his entire family, to his extended ''Intrepid'' family, and all those whose lives he has touched. Oskar Brecher, President Mark Kaufmann, Chair Judith S. Lewis, Rabbi Martin J. Zion, Rabbi Emeritus    FISHER-Zachary. Devoted Director and supporter of the entire law enforcement community. Our deepest sympathies to his brother Larry, nephew Tony, his family and staff. He will be sorely missed. On behalf of the Board of Directors of NY's Finest Foundation. Hon. Rodney Ettman, Chairman Hon. Shelly Goldfeder, Pres.    FISHER-Zachary. The Real Estate Board of New York mourns the passing of Zachary Fisher, a shaper of our city's splendid skyline and esteemed colleague and a distinguished public benefactor. We extend our sympathy to the Fisher family. Bernard H. Mendik, Chairperson Steven Spinola, President

abstract: PFEIFFER-Martha Goldhammer nee Addis, formerly of the Bronx, New York, died on May 5, 1999. Born on September 25, 1908. Daughter of Henrietta nee Weinberg and Percy Addis, widow of Rubin Pfeiffer, predeceased by her first husband, Isidore Goldhammer, and her son, Dr. Robert Goldhammer. Survived by her daughter-in-law, Florie Brettler Goldhammer, of Pittsburgh; granddaughters, Anne M. Goldhammer Moore, of Chicago, and Elizabeth P. Kuzma, of Pittsburgh; a great-granddaughter, Emily Morgan Kuzma, of Pittsburgh; and a brother, Aaron Addis, of Delray Beach, FL. After receiving her Master's degree from New York City's Hunter College in 1933, Mrs. Pfeiffer taught French, Latin, Italian & German at James Monroe and DeWitt Clinton high schools in New York City until her retirement in 1973. Memorial services will be held at the Goldhammer residence on Sunday, May 9, at 1 P.M. Instead of flowers, contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Disease Alliance of Western Pennsylvania, 5180 Campbell's Run Road, Pittsburgh, PA 15205, Attention: Martha Fenchak Bell.

abstract: Novartis AG says its profit in the second half of 1998 rose 20 percent to 2.51 billion Swiss francs ($1.7 billion) from 2.09 billion year earlier (S)
snippet: Novartis AG says its profit in the second half of 1998 rose 20 percent to 2.51 billion Swiss francs ($1.7 billion) from 2.09 billion year earlier (S)
lead_paragraph: Novartis A.G., the world's No. 3 drug maker, indicated yesterday that its profit in the second half of 1998 rose 20 percent on improved profit margins and on cost savings resulting from the merger that formed the company. The implied second-half profit at the company, which makes the hypertension drug Diovan and the Alzheimer's drug Exelon, rose to 2.51 billion Swiss francs ($1.7 billion) from 2.09 billion a year earlier.
headline.main: Novartis Profit Rises; Merger Savings Cited
headline.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS; Novartis Profit Rises; Merger Savings Cited

abstract: Jenny and and her husband had enjoyed 15 years of an emotionally and intellectually fulfilling marriage when he suffered a stroke and Jenny's whole life suddenly screeched to a halt. Instead of gradually recovering, over the next five years her husband got progressively worse. The stroke had unmasked or hastened the onset of Alzheimer's disease, and Jenny became his permanent de facto caretaker.    Gone, she said, was the ''very sweet, loving, gentle, kind human being'' who had shared her interest in art, music, travel and stimulating conversation. Gone was her protector. When she collapsed one day with blood clots that had lodged in her lungs, he said, ''What are you doing on the floor?'' and then stepped over her to attend to his own needs. Gone was the husband she knew and loved, a husband who now doesn't even notice her presence or absence.
lead_paragraph: Jenny and and her husband had enjoyed 15 years of an emotionally and intellectually fulfilling marriage when he suffered a stroke and Jenny's whole life suddenly screeched to a halt. abstract: Editorial praises decision by Fairport Baptist Homes and other mostly church-sponsored nursing homes to shape daily life around needs and preferences of aging residents, rather than that of institutions (M)
snippet: Editorial praises decision by Fairport Baptist Homes and other mostly church-sponsored nursing homes to shape daily life around needs and preferences of aging residents, rather than that of institutions (M)
lead_paragraph: At a Roman Catholic nursing home in Albany a year ago, the order of Carmelite nuns that runs it broke from tradition by asking the aged applicants who were about to become residents: ''What time do you like to get up in the morning? When do you like to have breakfast? What do you like to eat?'' The Teresian Home had decided to end the tyranny of structure and schedule that herds old people through the day in nursing homes across the country: up at 6:30 A.M., dressed for breakfast at 7:30 to 9, lunch at noon in a dining room with scores of others, showers at a certain time, naps at a certain time, dinner at 5 to 5:30 P.M. and back in bed by 8, two to a room, on long hallways.
headline.main: A Better Way to Treat the Old
headline.print_headline: A Better Way to Treat the Old

abstract: LITTLE known in New Jersey just three and a half years ago, assisted-living residences -- offering the frail but ambulatory elderly housing, social services and health care -- are blossoming throughout the state.     Since mid-1995, 5,500 new and renovated units have been developed, 3,600 more are under way and an additional 27,400 have been approved, according to the state's Department of Health and Senior Services, which licenses assisted-living projects.

abstract: KAHN-Harry. It is with great sadness that all of us at CEP will record the passing of Harry Kahn, a longtime member of the Board and past Chairman. Harry's enormous contribution to the CEP philosophy is endowed through the success the organization enjoys today; indeed, his strong sense of values and personal caring form an enduring memory which we, his successors, must always seek to emulate. Until only recently, Harry was helping and encouraging us with his depth of vision and ideas, his seeming endless energy and unbridled enthusiasm for CEP's future. He will be sorely missed. Gavin Anderson, Chairman     KAHN-Harry. The Board of Directors and staff of the National Child Labor Committee mourn the passing of their longtime friend and board member. A man of great dignity with a strong commitment to the well-being of all our nation's young people, he helped make sure that economic opportunity was more than just a phrase for millions of youth. His wisdom, his counsel, and his wit will be greatly missed. Jeffrey Newman, President and Executive Director Julianne Malveaux, Chairman, Board of Directors National Child Labor Committee     KAHN-Harry. It is with deep sadness that we mark the untimely passing of our friend and former Board member, Harry Kahn. A man of great charm, intellect, and accomplishment, he helped lead the NYC Chapter of the Alzheimer's Association during crucial times in our development. Our heartfelt condolences go out to his family and many friends. Eugene S. Callender, Co-President Irvine D. Flinn, Co-President John A. Jager, Exec. Director Jean Marks, Assoc. Exec. Director     KAHN-Harry. The Board of Trustees, the Director and the Staff of the Brooklyn Museum of Art record with deep sorrow the passing of art collector and philanthropist, Harry Kahn. A longtime friend of the Museum, he was a member of the Board of Trustees until 1997, a founding member of the Contemporary Art Council, and remained a member of the Acquisitions Committee until the time of his death. Robert S. Rubin, Chairman
lead_paragraph: KAHN-Harry. It is with great sadness that all of us at CEP will record the passing of Harry Kahn, a longtime member of the Board and past Chairman. Harry's enormous contribution to the CEP philosophy is endowed through the success the organization enjoys today; indeed, his strong sense of values and personal caring form an enduring memory which we, his successors, must always seek to emulate. Until only recently, Harry was helping and encouraging us with his depth of vision and ideas, his seeming endless energy and unbridled enthusiasm for CEP's future. He will be sorely missed. Gavin Anderson, Chairman

abstract: PINKHAM-Mary S. (''Bunnie''). On March 8, 1999. Born in New York City December 28, 1916, the dear daughter of the late William W. and Mary G. Struthers. Adoring wife of Richard Alden Ray Pinkham, whom she married in 1941, who died in 1997. Loving and dedicated mother of Mary P. (''Penny'') Janeway of Cambridge, MA, Richard Jr. of Rye, NY, David of Barrington, RI and Elizabeth P. (''Betty'') Anderson of Billings, MT. Delighted grandmother of Sam, Daisy, Laurie, Rick, Mary, Rosie, Jamie and Tim. Sister of Nina S. Bremer, Sara S. Frothingham and the late William W. Struthers, Jr. She lived in Rye, NY until 1981 when she and her husband moved to Hobe Sound, FL and Greenwich, CT. She was a student, teacher, parent, grandparent and President of the Board of Trustees of her dear alma mater, Rye Country Day School. When the School expanded to become co-ed through 12th grade, The Mary Struthers Pinkham Building was named in her honor. She served on the Board of Managers of the United Hospital, where her four children were born, and where she died. She also served on the Advisory Board of the Foundation for Children with Learning Disabilities. An athlete all her life, she was an All-American in lacrosse and field hockey, a notable tennis player, and a golfer in her later years. Her dearest friendships lasted a lifetime, and she was widely admired and loved for her loyalty, sense of duty, selflessness, uprightness and old-fashioned grace. She has gone from the double darkness of Alzheimer's and bereavement into the Light. We grieve and we rejoice. Family visitation at William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road in Rye on Wednesday, March 10 from 6:00 to 8:00 pm. Memorial service at 11:00 am, Thursday, March 11 at Christ Church, Milton Road, Rye. Contributions in her name may be made to the Rye Country Day School, Rye, New York 10580.

abstract: STEPHENS-Thomas J., a White Plains lawyer, died on March 2, 1999 in Briarcliff Manor, New York, after a long bout with Parkinson's disease. He was 76. Mr. Stephens was born in Brooklyn, New York on September 18, 1922. He graduated from Polytechnic Preparatory School in Brooklyn and Colgate University where he attended summer sessions in order to join the U.S. Army during World War II as a private in 1942. Mr. Stephens served in the 36th infantry division of the 5th Army and eventually rose to first lieutenant in command of a rifle company with the 7th Army. He served in North Africa, Italy, France and Germany and participated in numerous campaigns, including Rapido River, Monte Cassino, the Breakthrough at Anzio, the liberation of Rome, and the invasions of Southern France and the German Rhineland. He received a battlefield commission for heroic action beyond the line of duty, the Bronze Star with a cluster, five battle stars and the combat infantryman's badge, among other decorations. After the War, Mr. Stephens earned his law degree from Syracuse University and practiced in New York City before founding the firm Stephens & Buderwitz in White Plains, New York where he practiced for nearly 40 years. Mr. Stephens ran for mayor of White Plains in 1952 and was continually active in White Plains and Westcheter County affairs. He served as President of the Bar Association of White Plains, President of the YMCA, President of the Board of Trustees of the Presbyterian Church in White Plains and on the board of EM Industries and numerous other corporations. He was a member of the Whippoorwill Club in Armonk, New York. Mr. Stephens was instrumental in the planning and design of the Kingsley House residences on Barker Avenue in White Plains, restructured its sponsorship and funding and assured its completion after the initial program encountered difficulties prior to completion. Funeral services will be held at the White Plains Presbyterian Church 39 North Broadway, White Plains on Saturday, March 6, at 10:30 am. The family requests that, in lieu of flowers, donations be sent to the Alzheimer's Association. Mr. Stephens is survived by wife Inge of North Salem, New York, sister Margaret Christie, son Christopher, daughters Eleanor and Merielle and granddaughter, Lara.

abstract: GOLDHAR-Maxwell, 82, a man who enriched the lives of his family, friends and the people of Ontario, died suddenly at home Tuesday night from a heart attack. Still active in business and pursuing his dreams through his last days, Mr. Goldhar left major accomplishments and a loving circle of family and friends behind him. Mr. Goldhar devoted over 50 years of his life to voluntary service, and he was recently invested with the Order of Ontario. He was well known for his substantial contributions to technology, manufacturing and natural resources companies in Canada and internationally, in particular Ontario Store Fixtures, Fantom Technologies and Fifty Plus Net International. As a business leader he earned the nickname ''Dr. Business'' for his achievements in helping to ''turn around'' declining Ontario companies. Founding president of the President's Council of the Canadian Opera Company and a founding director of the York Racquet Club, Hockley Valley Ski Club and the Island Yacht Club, Mr. Goldhar was a leader who constructively countered the exclusion of Jews from many of the city's social organizations by opening new opportunities for them through these organizations. Mr. Goldhar was treasurer of the building campaign for the northern YMHA and served for many years as director of the Canadian Society for the Weizmann Institute of Science. At the time of his death, Mr. Goldhar was an active director of ''CARP,'' the Canadian Association of Retired Persons, and a founding director of Fifty Plus Net International, the leading Internet supplier to seniors in Canada. Mr. Goldhar recently joined the board of Sunnybrook and Women's Health Sciences Centre, and served as Chair of the Board of Women's College Health Research Inc. Previously, he served as the Chair of the Hospital Council of Metropolitan Toronto, Chair of the Board of both the Northwestern General Hospital and the Northwestern Health Centre Foundation, a director of Women's College Hospital and treasurer of the Alzheimer Association of Ontario. He is survived by his loving family: by his son, Dan, and Dan's wife, Janet; by daughters Nancy, Heather and Renanah and Heather's partner, James Neal; by his grandchildren Jeremy and Rachel; his brothers Albert and Morty and their wives Booty and Rosemary, respectively; and by his sister, Wendy Rue. Mr. Goldhar was predeceased by his wife of 50 years, Jeanette, and survived by his loving spouse, Marilou McPhedran. Services will be conducted at 2:30 PM today by Mr. Goldhar's close friend and tennis partner, Rabbi Gunther Plaut, at Holy Blossom Temple in Toronto.

abstract: Deborah Newquist is geriatric care manager in Newport Beach, Calif, occupation that did not exist when she received her master's degree in social work 24 years ago; field was born in response to nation's rapidly aging population and health care system's complexity; geriatric care managers, at $70 to $150 hour, generally do not offer hands-on care; part counselors and part social workers, they help manage health care, living arrangements and other affairs of their elderly clients; in doing so, they perform role once filled by families; photo (M)
snippet: Deborah Newquist is geriatric care manager in Newport Beach, Calif, occupation that did not exist when she received her master's degree in social work 24 years ago; field was born in response to nation's rapidly aging population and health care sy...
lead_paragraph: When an 86-year-old woman with Alzheimer's disease broke her hip, Deborah Newquist was the person who stayed with her at the hospital here. Years earlier, Dr. Newquist had arranged 24-hour home care for the woman and her bedridden husband, and she also took care of everything from having their house painted to getting their cat to the veterinarian.
headline.main: The Growing Business of Helping Elders Cope

abstract: Jack Anderson reviews Tere O'Connor Dance program at Kitchen (S)
snippet: Jack Anderson reviews Tere O'Connor Dance program at Kitchen (S)
lead_paragraph: Tere O'Connor's ''Hi Everybody!'' certainly wasn't boring. It couldn't have been. Mr. O'Connor changed his choreographic mind so often in it that no single subject ever grew dull. As presented on Thursday night at the Kitchen by Tere O'Connor Dance, the 45-minute piece touched on such matters as cancer, Alzheimer's disease, war, peace, retirement communities, gay marriage and homophobia, to name only a few of the topics that whizzed by to outbursts of recorded music by James Baker.

abstract: Ingram Micro chief executive Jerre L Stead notes that, despite huge drop in value of his stock options, which decreased from $54 a share a year ago to $18 now, he had always planned on giving away all his options wealth; photo (M)
snippet: Ingram Micro chief executive Jerre L Stead notes that, despite huge drop in value of his stock options, which decreased from $54 a share a year ago to $18 now, he had always planned on giving away all his options wealth; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: When Jerre L. Stead, chief executive of Ingram Micro, the world's largest computer distributor, says he was hoping that his stock options would be worth $100 million, he's unusual only in acknowledging an ambition that other chief executives keep to themselves. Mr. Stead was even more unusual in forgoing any salary since his hiring in 1996 to get even more options.

abstract: Surgeon general, Dr David Satcher, says that one in every five Americans experiences a mental disorder in any given year and that half of all Americans have such disorders at some time in their lives, but that most of them never seek treatment; says that many do not realize that effective treatments exist, that others fear being stigmatized and discriminated against and that still others are deterred from seeking treatment because they lack insurance that would cover it; says mental health must be part of mainstream health care, not an afterthought or an offshoot; endorses efforts by some states and members of Congress to eliminate disparities in insurance coverage for mental disorders and other illnesses; photo (M)

lead_paragraph: One in every five Americans experiences a mental disorder in any given year, and half of all Americans have such disorders at some time in their lives, but most of them never seek treatment, the surgeon general of the United States says in a comprehensive new report.

abstract: FISHER-Zachary. The partners of Fisher Brothers mourn the passing of our founder and partner Zachary Fisher and express our deepest condolences to his wife, Elizabeth, and the entire Fisher family. Zachary was a proud American, a leading real estate developer and a wonderful person. He helped to build New York City's skyline while devoting much of his life to the men and women in the U.S. Armed Forces. A recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom, Zachary founded the Intrepid Sea Air Space Museum; the Fisher House Program, which provides lodging for families of hospitalized military personnel; and the Fisher Armed Services Foundation, which makes contributions to military families who lose loved ones in tragic circumstances. Zachary also established the Fisher Center for Alzheimer's Disease Research at Rockefeller University. He touched and enriched many lives and will be sorely missed. A private memorial will be held aboard the Intrepid on today, June 7. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Intrepid Museum Foundation, 46th Street at 12th Avenue, New York City 10036. Fisher Brothers Larry Fisher Richard L. Fisher M. Anthony Fisher Arnold Fisher Kenneth Fisher Steven Fisher     FISHER-Zachary. The Partners of Cantor Fitzgerald mourn the passing of our dear friend Zachary Fisher, a true philanthropist and a great American whose many years of dedicated service to our country touched the lives of countless individuals. His visionary leadership in support of the men and women of the U.S. Armed Forces will be an inspiration to future generations. His leadership in the fields of scientific research, education and the arts will be sorely missed. We will miss his warm friendship and will cherish the memory of having known him. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his wife Elizabeth, his brother, his sister, his son, and the entire Fisher family. Allison and Howard Lutnick B.A. and Bud Flanagan Kent L. Karosen     FISHER-Zachary. The Board of Governors and members of the City Athletic Club record with sorrow the passing of Zachary Fisher. We are grateful for his wonderful generosity and boundless support of the club. He will be remembered as a highly esteemed presence among us. We would like to extend our deepest sympathies to his brother and fellow member, Larry Fisher, and to their family. Michael Todres, President     FISHER - Zachary. Saturday's Times ran not less than eleven tributes to my friend Zachary Fisher. All but one were from prestigious organizations to whom he gave counsel, money and leadership, and they were all well earned by him. This tribute is to the personal Zachary Fisher, the friend of a lifetime. My deepest sympathy to Elizabeth and to Larry. Lew Lubitz     FISHER-Zachary. The Association for a Better New York salutes its longstanding member. Our city and country will miss his intrepid leadership. We extend our deepest sympathy to the Fisher family. Lewis Rudin, Chairman

abstract: The vast majority of Americans will suffer from back pain at some point in their lives. In fact, only the common cold causes more employee absenteeism. Now, a study in the current issue of Science indicates that one of the most common back problems, intervertebral disk disease, or sciatica, may be an inherited disorder.    Sciatica is a painful condition in the region of the lower back and hip, affecting  about half of all people with serious back conditions.

abstract: Penn South Mutual Redevelopment Houses, a large moderate-income co-op complex on the west side of Eighth Avenue between 23d and 29th Streets, was seen as such an exemplary model of affordable housing for working families in 1962 that its dedication was attended by President John F. Kennedy, Eleanor Roosevelt, Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller and Robert Moses, who shaped much of the city in the post-war era. Now Penn South is on the verge of making a mark again.    In the 1960's, the complex attracted young families and older single people by the thousands, who could buy apartments for an average of $600 per room, plus monthly maintenance of $120. Because the complex has remained a relatively inexpensive place to live -- monthly maintenance is now about $500 for a two-bedroom apartment -- most of those who moved in early have never moved out.
lead_paragraph: Penn South Mutual Redevelopment Houses, a large moderate-income co-op complex on the west side of Eighth Avenue between 23d and 29th Streets, was seen as such an exemplary model of affordable housing for working families in 1962 that its dedication was attended by President John F. abstract: Best Bet      Having backed three ''New Century Commissions,'' Tilles Center finally gets to show what at least one of these investments has produced. Raphael Mostel's ''Travels of Babar: An Adventure in Scales'' makes its East Coast premiere on Saturday as part of Stage One: The Arts Start Here, a series for children ages 5 through 9 and their families. Told through narration, projected slides of illustrations from the original classic by Jean de Brunoff and an eight-piece orchestra playing music by Mr. Mostel, the piece recounts the adventures of King Babar and Queen Celeste. There are two performances, at 11 a.m. and 2 p.m., at Tilles on the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University in Brookville. (516) 299-3100.
lead_paragraph: Best Bet

headline.print_headline: THE GUIDE

abstract: EARLY on in ''Fight Club,'' I found myself exulting at the scary wit with which David Fincher was pulling things off and racking up a score. It was like watching some nerveless kid play pinball in a minefield, his body flexed into the machine, his shoulders and his arrogant hips seeming to drive it into Charlie Parker choruses of bell-ringing. It's a wonder to see such prowess, and in ''Fight Club'' (which opened Friday) I'm talking about not just the creation of some grunge-heaven city but the macabre yoking together of gallows humor and smash-mouth violence, the interplay of Edward Norton and Brad Pitt, nerd and Neo (in the sense of the Keanu Reeves icon from that empty but deeply influential film ''The Matrix''). But this is one of the most glossy and treacherous pieces of cinematic black ice we have yet encountered, with good old photography turning into effects beneath our drifting tires.    Then the pinball wizard grows bored with his own brilliance. He turns away, and in one ruinous glimpse you see that he's not just a child but a kind of retard, too. In anything but pinball, he's in his own Alzheimer's.
lead_paragraph: EARLY on in ''Fight Club,'' I found myself exulting at the scary wit with which David Fincher was pulling things off and racking up a score. It was like watching some nerveless kid play pinball in a minefield, his body flexed into the machine, his shoulders and his arrogant hips seeming to drive it into Charlie Parker choruses of bell-ringing. It's a wonder to see such prowess, and in ''Fight Club'' (which opened Friday) I'm talking about not just the creation of some grunge-heaven city but the macabre yoking together of gallows humor and smash-mouth violence, the interplay of Edward Norton and Brad Pitt, nerd and Neo (in the sense of the Keanu Reeves icon from that empty but deeply influential film ''The Matrix''). But this is one of the most glossy and treacherous pieces of cinematic black ice we have yet encountered, with good old photography turning into effects beneath our drifting tires.

abstract: The Ethicist column answers question about transferring assets in order to qualify for Medicaid nursing home care; also answers question on taking gasoline from closed service station, when driver has been led down dark road by sign (S)
snippet: The Ethicist column answers question about transferring assets in order to qualify for Medicaid nursing home care; also answers question on taking gasoline from closed service station, when driver has been led down dark road by sign (S)
lead_paragraph: My mother has Alzheimer's disease and her doctor has warned me that she soon will need to be placed in a nursing home. Several years ago, her lawyer advised me to transfer her assets to my name so that she could qualify for Medicaid and I could inherit her money. This is perfectly legal, and according to other people in the same situation I've spoken to, it is widely done. But is it ethical? /G.O.

lead_paragraph: One of the major surprises, and there are not many, about Ronald Harwood's "Quartet" at the Albery is that it is not in fact a revival. Not so much well written as well remembered from other well-made dramas of the past 40 years, this is a defiant end-of-century return to the kind of plays they are supposed not to be writing any more.

snippet: Hastings Center, bioethics research institute, relocates from Hanstings-on-Hudson to Garrison, NY; although there are about 20 other centers that study bioethics, Hastings Center is only one not connected to university or medical school (M)
lead_paragraph: THE Hastings Center, the bioethics research institute, has moved here from Hastings-on-Hudson where it began 30 years ago in the office of a co-founder, Will Gaylin, a psychoanalyst. But 14 of its 28 staff members commute from Westchester. One of them, Dr. Erik Parens of Sleepy Hollow, said, ''It's three times the distance, but even to a Westchester resident it's worth it. This is a spectacularly beautiful place to work.''

lead_paragraph: MY Meals-on-Wheels buddy, after a depressing run of visits, says to me ''When I get that old and decrepit, just shoot me.'' And we proceed to have a discussion on aging versus senility or infirmity and do-not-resuscitate orders and -- oops, we missed our turn, again. Sometimes, we get to talking so much that we bat a thousand: we actually miss our turn on every delivery for that day.

abstract: Lives column by Dale Peck explains his love of game of bridge; says like most gaming addicts, he loves rules, and bridge is game of Byzantine complexity, along with its own bureaucracy: bridge leagues, bridge clubs, bridge columns; describes his playing in bridge championship, the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional, tournament that lasted five days (M)
snippet: Lives column by Dale Peck explains his love of game of bridge; says like most gaming addicts, he loves rules, and bridge is game of Byzantine complexity, along with its own bureaucracy: bridge leagues, bridge clubs, bridge columns; describes his p...
lead_paragraph: Some people love sports; others prefer games. With the exception of Eddie Kantar, the only person to have played in a world bridge championship and a world table-tennis championship, these are not usually the same people. Hence the crowd at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional: the several hundred bridge enthusiasts gathered in the ballroom of the Crowne Plaza were generally elderly and obese, the younger participants geeks of the taped-together-spectacles variety. It's sobering to walk into a roomful of slope-shouldered card players and realize that you are One of Them, but whoever said addiction was pretty?
headline.main: Lives; Revenge of the Nerds
headline.print_headline: Lives; Revenge of the Nerds

abstract: Editorial Observer on George Stephanopoulos's book as latest tell-all account from White House insider, one that adds to concerns about how President can be effective if he feels he is surrounded by future memoirists; notes that Bill Clinton and Ronald Reagan, who could not be less alike, both inspired top appointees to start typing as soon as they were out the door
snippet: Editorial Observer on George Stephanopoulos's book as latest tell-all account from White House insider, one that adds to concerns about how President can be effective if he feels he is surrounded by future memoirists; notes that Bill Clinton and R...
lead_paragraph: George Stephanopoulos seems to feel bad, in retrospect, that he did not press Bill Clinton harder about what went on with Gennifer Flowers before jumping to his candidate's defense. ''I needed Clinton to see me as his defender, not his interrogator, which made me, of course, an enabler,'' he writes in his new memoir, ''All Too Human.'' Ambivalence and regret are the two main emotional chords in the book, but in this case Mr. Stephanopoulos seems to be beating himself up unnecessarily. Throughout American history, when a bimbo eruption has hit an American Presidential campaign, the last thing a candidates' aides have considered doing is asking the Big Guy for the real story. When Grover Cleveland was accused of having an illegitimate child, he ordered his advisers to ''tell the truth'' and went off to sulk for the rest of the campaign. Nobody ran after him to ask exactly what the truth was supposed to be.

abstract: Dudley Clendinen, in Editorial Observer column, notes that his mother, retired Tampa Tribune food editor, has refused to eat after she had stroke; says food has always been his mother's measure of life, and of control, and it may be that her desire for life has finally run out (M)
snippet: Dudley Clendinen, in Editorial Observer column, notes that his mother, retired Tampa Tribune food editor, has refused to eat after she had stroke; says food has always been his mother's measure of life, and of control, and it may be that her desir...
lead_paragraph: In the mornings, for breakfast or brunch, there was hot baked grapefruit with brown sugar, cheese grits, crusty egg casserole with parsley on top, country bacon salty and thick, and biscuits -- tiny warm clouds of air and flour, made for melting butter on. At lunch there were chilled salads of plump avocado and grapefruit sections, broiled tomatoes with parmesan cheese, tender asparagus spears, yellow squash casserole, cool fresh shrimp with hot sauce and lime, and iced tea with lemon and leaves of fragrant mint that grew under the faucet by the back porch steps. And squares of hot buttered cornbread, brown and crunchy at the edges.
headline.main: Editorial Observer; If the Food of Life Isn't Appetizing Anymore

abstract: Editorial in series Then-Now, Reflections on the Millennium, notes that seeming blessing of increased longevity is in fact mixed blessing; says medical knowledge has created new stage of life--extended old age, an age whose quality, effect on larger culture and true end are still unknown; says for the old themselves, for their families and caregivers and for social scientists and politicians, longer life span creates some painful new questions
snippet: Editorial in series Then-Now, Reflections on the Millennium, notes that seeming blessing of increased longevity is in fact mixed blessing; says medical knowledge has created new stage of life--extended old age, an age whose quality, effect on larg...
lead_paragraph: For all the people wondering how to celebrate the turn of a century that also turns a millennium, the greatest wonder is that there are so many people still alive to think about it. The dawning wonder -- and also worry, for those concerned about the quality of old age and the allocation of resources -- is how many babies born this centennial may still be alive for the next one.

abstract: Peter Marks reviews four one-act plays in Series B of Ensemble Studio Theater's Marathon '99 festival: The 'I' Word: Interns, by Michael Louis Wells, directed by Jamie Richards; Dreamtime for Alice, by Susan Kim, directed by Richard Lichte; The Golf Ball, by Frank D Gilroy, directed by Chris Smith; and In the Western Garden, by Stuart Spencer, directed by Judy Minor; photo (M)
snippet: Peter Marks reviews four one-act plays in Series B of Ensemble Studio Theater's Marathon '99 festival: The 'I' Word: Interns, by Michael Louis Wells, directed by Jamie Richards; Dreamtime for Alice, by Susan Kim, directed by Richard Lichte; The Go...
lead_paragraph: Alienation for all ages is the cold, hard theme running through the second part of Ensemble Studio Theater's series of one-act plays. Whether expressed in the ambition-guided guile of young White House aides in Michael Louis Wells's ''The 'I' Word: Interns,'' the faithless despair of a stranded middle-aged tourist in Susan Kim's ''Dreamtime for Alice'' or the aimless ennui of the old in ''The Golf Ball'' by Frank D. Gilroy, the focus is the crushing of the soul by cynicism and disenfranchisement.

lead_paragraph: This is one crowded town at the moment. With the National Baseball Hall of Fame holding its annual induction today and expecting record attendance, Main Street has been packed all weekend with fans dressed in the caps and jerseys of their favorite teams, hoping to glimpse their heroes. But the induction was not the only draw this weekend. abstract: * ''JUDY BERLIN,'' starring Edie Falco, Madeleine Kahn, Aaron Harnick and Bob Dishy. Directed by Eric Mendelsohn (not rated, 90 minutes). Much of Eric Mendelsohn's moody black-and-white first film is set in a sleepy Long Island town during the longest solar eclipse known to movies. The event transforms the place into a errie corner of ''The Twilight Zone'' suffused with a Checkhovian melancholy. Madeleine Kahn and Bob Dishy are a loquacious housewife and her long-suffering school-principal husband, and Aaron Harnick their depressed 30-year-old son, a failing filmmaker. Edie Falco, as a Hollywood-bound aspiring actress, is the only live wire in this heap of downed power lines — Stephen Holden\n
snippet: * ''JUDY BERLIN,'' starring Edie Falco, Madeleine Kahn, Aaron Harnick and Bob Dishy. Directed by Eric Mendelsohn (not rated, 90 minutes). Much of Eric Mendelsohn's moody black-and-white first film is set in a sleepy Long Island town during the lon...
lead_paragraph: Much of ''Judy Berlin,'' Eric Mendelsohn's evocatively eerie meditation on modern suburbia, takes place during what may be the longest solar eclipse known to movies. That solar event in the middle of a sleepy late September afternoon draws the lonely, withdrawn inhabitants of a middle-class Long Island town out of their immaculate houses to wander through the deserted streets like zombies stirring to life after a long, silent sleep. As they encounter one another in an apocalyptic gloom, in which the street lights seem to cast a nuclear glow, they tentatively reach out to reconnect with one another in ways they haven't done in years.
headline.main: Solar Eclipse of the Heart: Love in a Suburb of the 50's
headline.print_headline: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW; Solar Eclipse of the Heart: Love in a Suburb of the 50's

abstract: I REMAIN IN DARKNESS  By Annie Ernaux  94 pages. Seven Stories. $18.95.       Collectors of the slender, restrained and elliptical books of Annie Ernaux, which have been critical and commercial successes in France for a generation, will want to have ''I Remain in Darkness,'' even though it is a less gripping work than her earlier works. Ms. Ernaux, a professor of literature who lives outside Paris, has created something of a genre: the emotionally minimalist, stylistically uninflected chronicles of a hypersensitive middle-aged woman examining her own life and those of her parents. Her work represents a severely pared-down Proustianism, a testament to the persistent, haunting and melancholy quality of memory.
lead_paragraph: I REMAIN IN DARKNESS
headline.main: When a Parent Becomes the Child
headline.print_headline: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; When a Parent Becomes the Child

snippet: New York Yankees infielder Chuck Knoblauch discusses his preparations for playoff series against Texas Rangers; Knoblauch has made 26 errors this season; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Chuck Knoblauch says he does not have distressing visions of a grounder bounding to him at second base in the post-season and having something go terribly awry after he fields it. Knoblauch cannot think that he may throw the ball wildly to first base, as he has done so many times before. He will not think that way. Or, at least, that is what Knoblauch tells himself.

abstract: Brief summary of 'seven stages' of man, from infancy to old age; photos; graph (S)
snippet: Brief summary of 'seven stages' of man, from infancy to old age; photos; graph (S)
lead_paragraph: Men are often portrayed as big boys, differing from their younger selves only in the sums of money they spend on their toys. Indeed, because men can reproduce well into old age, and do not experience cyclical hormonal changes, their health is regarded as fairly static. But medical experts are learning that between the boy and the man stand a variety of genetic, biological and social changes. Understanding these factors may help men prepare for the stages that await them.
headline.main: The Seven Stages of Man
headline.print_headline: The Seven Stages of Man

abstract: In Georgia, Days of
snippet: In Georgia, Days of
lead_paragraph: SO what does the nicotine skin patch have to do with wine, golf champions and, yes, really cool sports cars? Royalties from the transdermal patch have helped to pay for the Panoz family's delightfully disparate conglomerate, a host of enterprises that includes Georgia's only serious winery and the company that builds a car the racing legend Parnelli Jones has dubbed ''the great American roadster.''

abstract: Dia Center Benefit  THURSDAY -- The Dia Center for the Arts will benefit from a reception and preview of the Armory Show 1999, from 6 to 9 P.M., at the 69th Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue at 26th Street. More than 75 dealers will display paintings, sculpture and photography. The show, to be open from Friday through Feb. 22, will commemorate the 1913 show, which introduced modern art to the United States. Preview tickets, $150, from (212) 293-5582.

abstract: Article on growth in community service among Long Island teenagers; some are self-motivated and others are doing so to meet high school graduation requirement; photos (M)
snippet: Article on growth in community service among Long Island teenagers; some are self-motivated and others are doing so to meet high school graduation requirement; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: FOR the last few years, Stacy Joseph, a senior at Half Hollow Hills West High School, has volunteered regularly at a soup kitchen in the basement of Trinity Lutheran Church in Wyandanch. Last summer, Floyd Feather, a sophomore at Port Washington High School, spent almost every day volunteering at the Long Island Alzheimer's Foundation office in New Hyde Park. Kara Kandel, a senior at Syosset High School, volunteers regularly for a group that holds special events for underprivileged and handicapped children.

abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on difficulties of dying, both for the person whose end is near and for family members and friends who love the one who is dying; contends dying is made no easier when death is unduly prolonged by life-sustaining medical instruments; though in recent decades both families and physicians have begun to discuss subject of death and dying more openly, there still appear to be wide gaps between what patients want for their last days and what doctors and other health professionals think they want; review of findings by Dr Peter A Singer, general internist and ethicist at University of Toronto, about what patients consider to be appropriate care for the end of life (M)
snippet: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on difficulties of dying, both for the person whose end is near and for family members and friends who love the one who is dying; contends dying is made no easier when death is unduly prolonged by life-sustainin...
lead_paragraph: In the insightful and poignant drama, ''Wit,'' now playing off-Broadway to wide acclaim, the protagonist -- a professor with advanced ovarian cancer that spreads despite aggressive medical treatment -- brings to light many of the issues that still make dying an unduly painful experience for far too many people in Western society. The professor writhes with intractable pain because her doctor fails to order the patient-controlled analgesia suggested by the oncology nurse. And when she finally takes her last breath, a team races in with machines ready to revive her, even though her chart clearly states that she does not want to be resuscitated.

abstract: Pres Clinton will announce $6 billion package of tax and budget proposals to help provide long-term care for people with chronic illnesses and disabilities in most ambitious effort to deal with long-term care needs of elderly since collapse of Administration's plan to guarantee health insurance for all Americans in 1994; core of initiative is to give tax credit of $1,000 annually to people who need long-term care, at home or in institution, and in some cases to those who care for relatives with serious physical ailments; White House says tax credit, if approved by Congress, will help two million people, at cost of $5.5 billion, from 2000 to 2004; Republican House Ways and Means Committee member Repr Ari Fleischer says initiative is good idea with potential to be enacted into law, describing it as part of House Republican manifesto, or so-called Contract With America, expounded in 1994 and 1995; notes Republicans and Democrats alike have in past resisted some of Clinton's proposals for business-tax increases, adding that long-term care changes will have better chance of approval if not linked to such increases (M)
snippet: Pres Clinton will announce $6 billion package of tax and budget proposals to help provide long-term care for people with chronic illnesses and disabilities in most ambitious effort to deal with long-term care needs of elderly since collapse of Adm...

abstract: Zeneca, whose drug tamoxifen, sold under brand name Nolvadex, is only drug approved in United States to reduce incidence of breast cancer in high-risk postmenopausal women, is suing Eli Lilly & Co, charging its sales force falsely tell doctors that its osteoporosis drug raloxifene, sold under name Evista, can prevent breast cancer and can be used in place of Nolvadex; Lilly is countersuing, denying charge and demanding Zeneca stop its comments about Lilly sales force; Food and Drug Administration has already ordered both companies to drop consumer advertisements that imply Evista can prevent breast cancer and that fail to mention Nolvadex's risks; companies are first to jockey for position in cancer prevention market (M)
snippet: Zeneca, whose drug tamoxifen, sold under brand name Nolvadex, is only drug approved in United States to reduce incidence of breast cancer in high-risk postmenopausal women, is suing Eli Lilly & Co, charging its sales force falsely tell doctors tha...
lead_paragraph: Two drug companies seeking to tap the vast market of postmenopausal women at risk for breast cancer, heart disease and bone loss have clashed with each other and run afoul of the Food and Drug Administration over their marketing practices, prompting a flurry of lawsuits, Government warning letters and accusations that inaccurate assertions could endanger women's health.

lead_paragraph: THINKING of starting or investing in a business to serve retired people? The monthly luncheon of the Desert Newcomers, a club for retired women who recently moved to Las Vegas, might be a good place to do market research, except for one hitch. The ladies do not like to talk business. Desert Newcomers is strictly a social club.
